Title
* Consider removing the brackets.

Goal
* Please modify the definition of "summit" as follows:
  • Add "a sequence of" before "any".
  • Add "consecutive" after "number of".
  • Add "immediate" before "bottom-left".
  • Add "immediate" before "bottom-right".
  • Add "of that sequence" after "bottom-left".
  • Add "of that sequence" after "bottom-right".

* Please specify whether two summits can share the same characters, or they must be disjoint.

Constraints
* Please change "two special 4x3 pattern never overlap" to "no two special 4x3 patterns overlap".

* Can the final sentence of the third constraint be removed? The first sentence seems sufficiently clear on its own.

Cases
* Aligned mountains (Test/Validator 4): The third constraint is violated.

* No hidden pass (Test/Validator 6): Should the output be 5 instead of 3? If not, why?

* Partially hidden summit (Validator 9): Please remove the trailing newline from the input.

* Is it possible or impossible to have a case where /\ appears consecutively?

Thanks.

This differs from an approach where summits and ridges are defined explicitly, so the correct answer follows directly from the rules and alternative interpretations are ruled out.

This is why I said the ambiguity is resolved procedurally rather than definitionally, which, in my view, does not fully address the underlying issue.

On the other hand, I could keep a short and very slightly ambiguous statement.

I've performed a deeper review of the puzzle.

The puzzle statement appears to encourage the following high-level approach:

1. Identify the ridges.
2. For each ridge, complete its hidden sections.
3. Identify and count summits on each completed ridge.
4. Sum the total number of summits.

This expectation is strongly suggested by the example, which explicitly reconstructs three complete ridges (front, middle, and back), including characters that do not appear in the original input. The example then relies on those completed ridges to justify the final summit count. The detailed rules describing how hidden sections may be completed further reinforce the idea that ridge reconstruction is required to finish the task.

While the statement makes this overall goal clear, some of the reconstruction mechanics that the example implicitly relies on are not stated explicitly. Without those being made clear, different readers may reasonably interpret the reconstruction process differently, potentially leading to different answers.

*** Identifying ridges ***

The example shows that visible portions of the input must be associated into distinct ridges before summits can be counted.

The definition of a ridge is clear, but other than that, the statement does not give further guidance on:

(a) how the input should be disaggregated into ridge sections, and

(b) when two ridge sections should be treated as belonging to the same ridge.

*** Completing hidden sections ***

The statement specifies which characters are allowed when completing hidden sections of a ridge in different situations, which is the most critical rule. However, because ridge reconstruction is necessary in order to apply the summit definition, additional rules appear necessary to avoid unintended interpretations.

In particular, the example suggests that, after a ridge is completed:

* Each ridge occupies exactly one non-space character per column.

* Characters along a ridge form a continuous path across adjacent columns. That means non-space characters in adjacent columns must be in adjacent rows, except when both are {{-}}, in which case both must be in the same row.

* Non-space characters used to fill the hidden sections must lie below the initially visible mountain outline (they cannot be above it because they wouldn't be hidden in the first place).

I suggest to state such rules explicitly, as without them there may be multiple valid ways to complete hidden sections that differ structurally rather than merely cosmetically.

It also appears that while there may be multiple valid ways to fill hidden sections under the stated rules, the number of summits remains invariant across all valid completions. Making this invariant explicit would help readers understand that reconstruction serves only to enable summit identification, rather than to determine a unique completed shape.

*** Role of 4x3 patterns ***

The six 4x3 intersection patterns are clearly listed and illustrated, and their purpose is to indicate where one ridge hides another and to constrain how hidden sections may be completed. The statement requires readers to recognise and reason about these patterns explicitly.

However, when exploring how hidden ridges can be completed, it appears that the relative positions of the visible endpoints of ridge segments play a more direct role in determining valid completions than the specific 4x3 patterns themselves.

It may therefore be possible to simplify the presentation by expressing the completion rules in terms of the relative positions of the visible endpoints of a ridge segment (including edge-of-grid cases), without explicitly referring to the 4×3 patterns. Such a reformulation could preserve the puzzle’s intended complexity while reducing cognitive overhead for readers.

Below is a simplified approach for your consideration:

Let A be the rightmost character in the visible section to the left of a gap, and B be the leftmost character of the section to the right of the gap.

* If B is lower than A, fill the gap using {{-}} and {{\}}.

* If B is higher than A, fill the gap using {{-}} and {{/}}.

* If B is at the same height as A (i.e. in the same row), fill the gap using {{-}} only (since both A and B must be {{-}}; all other cases are invalid).

Edge-of-grid cases:

(It isn't necessary to extend the ridge beyond the grid boundaries, but doing so can make it easier to visualise whether a summit is partially cut off at the edges.)

* To extend beyond the left edge of the grid, use {{/}}.

* To extend beyond the right edge of the grid, use {{\\}}.

For reference, I've also drawn a table listing all possible scenarios under these simplified rules: https://pastebin.com/JaQ8Jw4Q

I have a few other observations as well, but it may be best to review the points above first.

Thanks.

The main risk I see is in cases such as "Partially hidden summit" (Test/Validator 7), where nothing in the statement explicitly suggests that two incomplete ridge segments should be grouped as part of the same ridge.

To reduce this ambiguity, I suggest adding a high-level sentence such as:

Non-space characters that can be connected into a continuous path across columns while satisfying the completion rules belong to the same ridge.

I believe this captures the intended behaviour, though please correct me if I'm misunderstanding the model.

To make room for the above sentence, a few small cuts could be considered:

  • The last two lines of the middle ridge illustration may be redundant with the updated example.

  • The phrase "with 5 summits" in the section on intersections could be removed.
  
  • The word "several" could be removed from the rules in the final section without loss of meaning.

Goal - minor editorial notes
* I'm not sure what "28 / going upwards and" refers to; could this be removed?

* Please add a period after "in the first place)".

Constraints
* What's the significance of the third constraint? Can it be removed?

Cases
* From a puzzle-solving perspective, some later test cases appear to introduce concepts earlier than expected, which can make incremental development harder. For example, when I ignore partially hidden summits (those hidden by other mountains rather than cut off at the grid edges), all cases pass except for:

  • Partially hidden summit (Test/Validator 7)
  • Two in front of three (Test/Validator 9)
  • Four in front of one flat summit (Test/Validator 12)
  • One in front of three (Test/Validator 14)
  • 8 pointed summits + 1 flat (Test/Validator 15)

This suggests that it might be better for these cases to be moved to the end. Some of the remaining cases may also benefit from reordering by increasing complexity.

More generally, introducing rules gradually and increasing difficulty across the cases (ideally in an order that mirrors the statement) could improve the solving experience. That said, I'll trust your judgment on how best to reorder them.

* Given how much the statement has evolved since version 1, I'm also wondering about overall case coverage. I'll review this further, but I'd be interested in hearing your thoughts as well.

Thanks.
